title: LAIR ORB / wiresinglass
description: A brief convo with Interfacing about the times they made computer parts with glass

dialogueTree.title: Interfacing: "This isn't just glass -- these are..."
dialogueTree.text: This isn't just glass -- these are old computation components.

links.title: Interfacing: "Yes. Filament memories. From the ti..."
links.text: Yes. Filament memories. From the time when wires were cast in glass; slides with an inlaid nervous system.

links.title: You: "How'd they do that? And why?"
links.text: How'd they do that? And why?

links.title: Interfacing: "The 'how' was a closely guarded sec..."
links.text: The 'how' was a closely guarded secret. Something that was locked in safes and human heads across the river where they were manufactured. As to why? Your fingers don't know.

links.title: Encyclopedia: "The 'why' is easy -- because they h..."
links.text: The 'why' is easy -- because they hadn't come up with modern silicon-based systems yet. For vitreous-cast filament memories, though, these seem incredibly advanced.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant tilts his head, watc..."
links.text: The lieutenant tilts his head, watching the light glimmer on the glass. "So it is. I think these used to form a single system, slotted in the wall."

links.title: You: ""So this is all that remains of Fel..."
links.text: "So this is all that remains of Feld R&D?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "He nods. "The rest of the building..."
links.text: He nods. "The rest of the building seems to have been picked clean."

links.title: You: ""Could this be part of the Feld Pla..."
links.text: "Could this be part of the Feld Playback Experiment?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""These? No. These are old filament..."
links.text: "These? No. These are old filament memories. I hope you're not expecting to find that device here -- you will be disappointed."

links.title: Inland Empire: "All you will find here is pain."
links.text: All you will find here is pain.
